title: Most wedding vows specify 'till death do us part.' Is this still realistic and what would you propose as a substitute? - Quora

response.answer_text: Whether or not it's realistic depends on the choices you and your spouse make. You could both decide to remain married until death, no matter how miserable you become. People in societies that stigmatize divorce do exactly that. Even if they hate their spouse, they don't leave. If that sounds nice to you, go for it. Of course, if you don't want to promise to remain married until death, then don't. No one's forcing you. When my husband and I got married, we wrote our own vows, and we didn't include anything about the duration of our marriage. We are both aware that there are circumstances that could cause us to divorce. If he starts beating me, I'll divorce him. If I start spending all our money on hookers and blow, he'll divorce me. And so on and so forth. Honestly, I think it's sort of pathological to promise to stay with someone for the rest of your life, regardless of how they behave. Because I take promises seriously, I wasn't interested in making a promise I knew I might break. Instead, I promised to do the things that maximize the chances of a lifelong happy marriage: Listen to him, respect him, be kind to him, tell him the truth, stuff like that. I'd rather promise to study two hours a day than promise to get my degree. It amuses me when people insist that there's no point in getting married unless you promise to be together forever. Apparently they don't care about the thousand-odd rights and responsibilities of marriage and don't see why anyone else would care about them. And they're either the sort who would stay with someone who abused them and made them miserable — which is certainly their prerogative — or they're hypocrites. If they know that something could make them leave, they're just like me, except I'm honest about it.

Hm…I did not know people actually used that outside of TV and movies. I’m trying to recall if I’ve seen anyone actually use those vows…can’t recall. In the Jewish tradition, we make a fair number of wedding blessings, seven, to be exact. But we don’t call them vows at all, we call them blessings or benedictions. You can see a nice translation of those at http://kerem.org, Seven Wedding Blessings. The legal part of the wedding is in the marriage contract, called the ketubah, and in its most ancient verbiage, it specifically describes what the groom must pay the bride if they divorce. No “till death” stuff. And those laws never claimed no divorce. The Hebrew Bible does not claim there is no divorce. My tradition assumes “till death” is a goal, not an oath. Jewish tradition considers the sin is to make an oath that you don’t know you can keep, since it is considered a sin to break an oath. The contract is all about what things of value you bring to the marriage, and what you will pay if you break it. It is the original prenuptial agreement. You can see the text here: Text of Orthodox Ketubah. In the modern version, it is nearly identical, but adds “the Lieberman clause” which allows for civil divorce if one person wants a divorce, and the other is making things difficult. You can see variations on the theme here: What is the difference between texts? The traditional words that are spoken by the actual groom (traditionally) and bride (in modern times, with some editing), are: “Behold, by this ring you are consecrated to me as my wife according to the laws of Moses and Israel.” For a variety of Jewish vows, check out this link, Choose your text Ketubah and click the link near the top/right of the page, where it says, “View Text.” From there you can choose the different texts, and see a bunch of different options. For the most modern, choose “English Only.”  The problem is in the question: looking for a “substitute” for something that is not required in the first place. Don’t look for a substitute. Put in what you want to vow.

To answer this question, I have to give a bit of a background. When I got married, I was so sick. I had influenza, and later got Mono, which was kind of a nightmare. Top it off with a control freak of a minister, a sociopathic brother in law that was running the show, and an abusive mother in law, I pretty much wanted to die rather than get married. There was no discussion of vows, no cute writing vows or anything like that. Instead, my wedding dress was inspected to see if it was modest enough. My veil was proclaimed too fancy and I had to wear a kerchief tied under my chin instead or I would offend my father in law to be. So, when we got married, there were no vows. No promises to the death or otherwise. The “minister” (and I use that term lightly), was so into putting on a show for the attendees, he spent two hours preaching a sermon that he translated himself in English and Russian. He claimed to have “forgotten” about vows. So, after wedding clean up was done, my brother in law took my new husband and I to the basement, sat us down and said, “Promise each other.” I said something generic like, “Um, um, I will always love you.” (I was sick and really had no idea what to say, so went with what I thought I should say.) My husband says, “I will love you and care for you, unless you commit adultery. Then I will never forgive you.” (I found out later that he included rape in this as well as other acts that he considered to be intimate, such as a hug or brief shoulder rub). So, do I think that “till death do you part.” should be included in marriage vows? No. I don’t. For the simple reason that I know people that have allowed themselves trapped in abusive marriages because they believe that because they made a promise in front of witnesses, they should fulfill them and until he kills her or the other way around, that is better than divorce. I personally do not believe that. I go back to my sham of a marriage and the “promises” we made, where if I was not only 18, sick, weak and unable to hardly hold myself up straight, I would have turned and walked away from him right then. I was a strong person, but months of fasting, sickness and brain numbing manipulation had worn me down until I didn’t know what to do or how to respond. Don’t put yourself in the position of “promising” something in the beginning that you may not be able to keep. And moral of the story, if you skip the vows, and your husband thinks that it is a good idea to tell you it is your fault if you get raped from the first night of your marriage, and he will never forgive you for it, turn and walk away then. As a substitute, I would say make vows something that you think that will make your marriage a healthy one and something that will reflect that.

While I suspect other religions use phrases with similar intent, I doubt they use those specific words. Given that Christians are not a majority of the world’s population, it is certain that “most” couples do not actually say those words. Many Christian wedding vows that are taken from various denomination’s Books of Prayer use those words. Some people marry in churches / denominations that don’t allow them to alter the words. Other people marry and decide those are the right words for them. Lots of people write their own vows. Some of those people include similar words; others don’t. If you believe “most” people say those words, you probably attend mostly Christian, mostly church weddings, and likely, those weddings involve people marrying for the first time. I suspect the odds shift as people get older, get away from church, and marry again. I have no interest in modifying traditional religious wording. If it works for you, follow it. We said, “henceforth and forevermore.”

It is a personal decision. In order for you to know if a promise that you are about to give is realistic, you need to know yourself good enough first. In our case, there was no question about it. I would not even bother marrying and spending a single dime if a bunch of “what-ifs” came up before the ceremony. I am either all in - or out. And my wife is exactly the same way in this. Civil marriage to us was not much more than a societal requirement you can enter and leave at will, just like a leasing agreement for a car. Actually, these days it is harder to get out of a car lease than out of civil marriage. It lacks true significance. That is why we got married by the Catholic church afterwards. Here, your vows are already established. No substitutes. Followed by: “What God just has united shall not be separated by man” That is valid until the death of one of the spouses. Is this for everybody? No, not really. Even the Church calls marriage a “vocational sacrament”. So the ones who are feeling inclined to be realistically able to follow through on such a promise - go ahead and marry until death do us part. I have never felt any particular hardship to keep my promise. It is basically just a loyalty thing, I would not call this love. But loyalty is so old fashioned. “Whimsical” is so much more fun, it seems. But it is also true that these days, too many folks find it a challenge to behave like a decent human being.

’Til death do us part is what I promised my husband - standing before God, our Pastor, our families, and about 400 friends. ’Til death do us part is what I meant with all my heart. ’Til death do us part is what I still mean every day, even when I’ve struggled. It is as real to me as our wedding bands. It is as real to me as our two children. It is as real to me as our best day, and it is as real to me as our worst day. ’Til death do us part is why we must work out our differences. It is what keeps up together when we’re exhausted. It’s part of what kept me going through mild (yet challenging) postpartum depression. It’s part of the very fiber of who I am as a wife. ’Til death do us part is exactly the way God designed marriage to be. I believe it is relevant for all. I believe it should be recommended for all. I believe it is the only path for me. I hope that parting is very, very far away.

Yes it definitely is. People who get married (except arranged marriages) do it because they can't imagine spending their life with anyone else. If you take out “till death do us part”, it would reduce weddings to a very expensive and elaborate party just to say “I do, for now”. In that case, why not live together until something or someone breaks a couple up instead? Why get married? Why should there be a commitment? Vows need to be serious because the act of getting married is serious. You don't quit on your husband or wife when life gets rough. It’s not a fling or a or a short term deal. You’re a team, you work through the tough times. Bailing should only be an option when all else fails, when you tried all you could but couldn't turn it around. The work it takes to maintain a marriage cannot be half-assed. Marriage vows shouldn't be either.

Q.: Most wedding vows specify "till death do us part." Is this still realistic and what would you propose as a substitute? It’s A tradition, a religious one at thatA fairy tale mindset indoctrinated into the very young and impressionableArchaic now that most people in the developed world live into their 70’s and beyondUsed as a moral high horse by some (conscious or subconscious), ie “look at me! I’m still married” when there all these ‘failed’ human beings (divorcees) traipsing aboutSo, no longer is it realistic, it never has been. But more importantly it isn’t practical or moral. There are plenty of answers already explaining the latter. As for a suitable substitute: “Til we part” You don’t need death in there. What a massive bummer!

The first time I got married, the part about death bugged me not because I had any doubts about the marriage lasting, but because the man I was marrying had already been diagnosed with lung cancer. We wrote our own vows, steering clear of everything about sickness and health, death and life, religion, and several other things we felt didn’t reflect our values or our commitment to one another. If you don’t like those words, or any other words, write them out. Just because there’s an established ritual, doesn’t mean you have to follow it. One of the things I said during that wedding was, “I make no promises today, because all the promises have already been made.” For help and inspiration blazing your own trail, search the web, and you will find wedding vows and ceremonies for atheists, for denominations which proscribe oaths, and many other variations. Mix and match the parts that suit you and your spouse-to-be, add poems, stories (including your own), or songs you like, and let your officiant know your preferences and plans.

What has changed that would make you think we ought to change it? You might talk about life expectancy changes, but life expectancy percentages were grossly skewed by infant mortality. Those 35–40 year life expectancy numbers were at birth, after infanthood it increased significantly. So the idea that marriage was for a few years is wrong. In my opinion, it’s realistic unless there is infidelity or abuse. So I don’t propose a substitute. So if you’re going into marriage expecting to cheat or abuse, or you expect to be cheated on or abused, my advice is don’t go through with it. All you’re accomplishing is a legal stranglehold on your property.

I think those words are fine - provided you view them as a sincere statement of intention, not an unbreakable contract. Life being what it is, nobody can predict what will happen in many years time, and I think it ridiculous to imagine you can enter into an unbreakable agreement at any time. The important point is that both parties intend the relationship to be open ended, indefinite, and that they will endeavour to make it so, But nonetheless, it is a wish, not a fact. And “for the foreseeable future”, “until it can no longer be made to work” and so on sound unbearably equivocal. If you cannot have a positive attitude going into marriage, when can you?

Q: Most wedding vows specify "till death do us part." Is this still realistic and what would you propose as a substitute? 10 year contracts with agreed severance terms that automatically roll over for a further period unless either party cancels? Just running up to my second renewal having married on Friday 13 Jan, 1989!

I would never condone a change to these vows! If an engaged couple want something “less emotionally binding”, then they can go to a “Justice of the Peace” and respond with, “Whatever!”, to all of the questions.
If that is how you feel, then no point in getting married at all. It will be an open ended arrangement where either can leave when they feel like it.
